These forests are gifts of nature.
Besides these forests naturally developed forests, there are man made forests too, which are developed artificially over a vast area of land.
These are called artificial forests or gardens.
For example, we have the rubber plantation of Ramu of Cox's Bazar.
The products derived from forest are known as forest resources.
Besides trees, shrubs and creepers, various types of insects, animals and birds are found in the forest.
These plants and creepers, animas, birds and insects together form the forest environment.
Timber bamboo, corn, fruits, honey, wax etc are collected from the forests of Bangladesh.
For the economic development of any country, 25% of the total land area should be covered with forest.
According to the survey of 1995-96 the measurement of forest land was 20 thousand square kilometer of the total area of Bangladesh.
That means only 13.6% forest land of the total area of Bangladesh.
Actually this rate is decreasing every year due to the deforestation.
Most of the forests of Bangladesh are located in south-east and south west of the country.
The location of the forest regions of Bangladesh is shown in the map.
On the basis of location, soil, climate and area, the whole forest regions of Bangladesh is dividing into four classes.

Both evergreen and deciduous trees are present in these forests.
In the hilly forest some trees are about 30.48 metres tall.
The main characteristic of these forests is co- existence of different types of trees.
The predominent trees gowing in this forest are Chaplaish, Telsur, Garjan, Jarul, Mehagany, Koroi, Gamar, Chhatim, Shimul, Mahua, Teak, Shishu, Bamboo, Bay-leaf, Palm and Rubber.
Moreover, animals like elephant, bear, monkey, tiger, wild cock and thousands of different types of birds are seen in these hilly forests.
Depending on the hilly forest resources available in these areas Karnafully paper mills, Sylhet paper and pulp mills, Karnafully Rayon mills are running productions.
The cottage industry developed in Sylhet, is mainly owing to the abundance of cane and bamboo available in the forests of that region.
The managrove or Saline water forest: The forest of the saline water of South west coast of Bangladesh is called mangrove forest.
This forest is the largest in Bangladesh and one of the most important mangrove forests in the world.
This famous forest is known as the Sundarbans.
This forest expands over an area of 6,786 square known as pneumataphores through which exchange of gases takes place.
Sundari is the main tree of this forest.
Every day, this forest is inundated with saline water due to tide.
Plenty of trees like Sundari, Gewa, Gorna, Dhundal, Pussur.
Kewar, Ora, Amar, Baain, Kakar etc. grow here.
Golpata is a prominent tree in the Sundarbans.
The leaves of this plant are used for making roofs and fencing.
Huge amount of honey is collected from this forest.
Usually honey is collected during the kilometer.
It occupies 6,724 square kilometer of land in Satkhira, Khulna and Bagerhat districts and 62 square kilometer in Barguna and Patuakhali districts.
This Sundarbans is bounded by the Buleswar river on the east, and Raimangal river on the west.
The characteristics of the trees of this forest differ from those of other forests in the country.
The trees have special roots for their respiration.
The roots are months of April, May and June.
Sundarbans is the dwelling place of a rare wild species of tigers the famous Royal Bengal Tiger.
In addition, many other animals, such as spotted deer, monkey, wild pig, python, crocodile and different species of birds are also found.

At present the sapling of Rubber, Aksashmoni, Arjun trees are being planted in this forest.
Wild cat, monkey, lemure, fox, bagdasa and varities of birds are seen in this forest.
There are some forests in some parts s of Barendra land in North Bengal.
The environment of these forests is almost similar to that of Madhupur forest.
Saal, Taal (Pots) etc trees grow in this forests.
Other forests: These forests are scattered in different parts of the plain lands in Dhaka, Rangpur, Dinajpur, Rajshahi, Comilla districts.
The total area of these forests is approximately 1.2 lac hector.
Besides this small forests are seen in some other parts of Bangladesh.
The forest resources like woods, branches and leaves are used as fuels.
Forest supply us very useful raw materials for industries.
The raw materials needed for producing pulp, papers, matches, sticks, rayon etc. are collected from forests.
Forest resources are also used in making ships, launches, boats, houses, posts, hard boards and furniture.
Bees make beehives in the forest and a huge quantity honey and wax are derived from these beehives.
The importance of forest is boundless in maintaining the balance of the environment.
Forests play important roles in controlling the weather and climate of a place.
Forest protects the country from natural calamities like storm, cyclone and flood etc. Forest helps wild animals to live and survive safely.
Forest also help in the reproduction of wild animals.
Forest controls the wind direction.
Forest prevents soil erosion and increases soil fertility.
Forest keeps weather cool and helps rainfall.
Plants of the forest keep the air fresh and clean by absorbing excess carbon-dioxide from the air and by supplying oxygen in the atmosphere.
It protects canals, beels and rivers etc. from silting.
It protects the environment form green house effect.
D. Conservation of forest resources; The economic development of Bangladesh depends to a great extent on the development of forest resources.
Due to increase of population the area of natural forest is gradually decreasing.
Moreover, since the forest area is quite inadequate in terms of what is needed, it has to be expanded.
Measures taken for the development of forest resource People have been encouraged to create forests by planting environmentfriendly trees in waste lands.
Forest Industry Development Corporation of Bangladesh has established a forest training institute in Sylhet.
One forest resource testing laboratory has been established at Chittagong.
A new horizon has been created in the cultivation of Tendu leaves and rubber plant in the forest area of Cox's bazar.
Rubber plantation is being done at Ramu, Raujan, Fatikchari and at Rashidpur of Moulovibazar.
Plantation of rubber is also extended to Rangamati, Cox's bazar, Chittagong, Banderban, Khagrachari, Sylhet, Hobiganj.

To attract and encourage people for forestation, Government has undertaken social and community forestation programs.
Arrangements have been made to supply the saplings of wood trees and fruit trees to the people at a minimum price during tree plantation season.
Government is strictly following 1990 forest act and 1974 wild life conservation act.
